Authors:
E. W. A. Boehm, Guy Marson, Geir H Mathiassen, Alain
Gardiennet, Conrad L Schoch
Title:
An overview of the genus Glyphium and its phylogenetic
placement in Patellariales
Abstract:
The genus Glyphium Nitschke ex F. Lehm. is characterized
by erect, carbonaceous ligulate to dolabrate ascomata, which are
strongly laterally compressed, and dehisce along a longitudinal slit,
running parallel to the compressed axis of the sporocarp. The five
currently recognized species are separated primarily by whether the
ascospores disassociate into part-spores within the ascus. The genus has
traditionally been classified in the Mytilinidiaceae Kirschst.
(Mytilinidiales, Pleosporomycetidae, Dothideomycetes). The present
study, based on fresh material representing European specimens of G.
elatum and G. grisonense, was initiated to determine the correct
phylogenetic placement of the genus Glyphium. Phylogenies using DNA
sequence obtained from 5 marker genes (nuLSU, nuSSU, mtSSU, TEF1, RPB1)
derived from six accessions, four from type species, G. elatum, and two
from G. grisonense, clearly indicate that the genus Glyphium belongs
within the Pleosporomycetidae, within the Dothideomycetes. This
supported close affinities with Patellaria and Hysteropatella, in the
Patellariales. The nomenclatural history of Glyphium is reviewed and a
key to world species given. The discrepancy between morphological and
phylogenetic classification of this genus is suggested to derive from
convergent morphological evolution.
